ygData.subject: New paper on arxiv: Illuminating search spaces by mapping elites
ygData.msgSnippet: Dear all, Jeff Clune and I are pleased to announce a new algorithm called the multi-dimensional archive of phenotypic elites, or MAP-Elites. We have posted a

Subject: New paper on arxiv: Illuminating search spaces by mapping elites
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=517809752
From: Jean-Baptiste Mouret <jeanbaptiste.mouret@...>

Dear all,

Jeff Clune and I are pleased to announce a new algorithm called =
the multi-dimensional archive of phenotypic elites, or MAP-Elites. We have =
posted a very preliminary draft of a paper about it on arXiv: http://arxiv.=
org/abs/1504.04909

We previously described MAP-Elites in our soon-to-be-pu=
blished paper about damage recovery in robotics (see http://arxiv.org/abs/1=
407.3501); the new paper is dedicated to MAP-Elites and provide many new ex=
periments and discussions.

MAP-Elites aims to find the highest performing =
solution at each point in a =93feature space=94 or =93behavior space=94, wh=
ere the user gets to choose the dimensions of the feature space. For exampl=
e, one could look for the fastest robot at each point in a 2D space where h=
eight and weight are on the x and y axes. Alternately, one could search for=
 the highest performing neural network at each combination of modularity an=
d network depth, or network depth and number of connections, or whichever d=
imensions one is interested in. MAP-Elites can thus also be seen as a form =
of dimensionality reduction, searching through a very high-dimensional sear=
ch space (e.g. the space of all robots, or all neural networks) to find the=
 highest-performing option at each point in a user-defined, low-dimensional=
 space. The algorithm itself is very simple (simpler than a basic GA!) but =
it leads to many interesting results: we used it to evolve neural networks,=
 virtual creatures, and basic controllers for a soft physical robot.

Becau=
se there was not previously a name for these type of algorithms that look f=
or the highest performing solution at each point in a feature/phenotype/beh=
avior space, in this paper we suggest the term =93Illumination Algorithms.=
=94 That is because these types of algorithms reveal the fitness potential =
of each area in a feature/behavior/phenotype space, and thus illuminate suc=
h spaces and help us better understand and visualize them. Illumination alg=
orithms also find a diversity of high-performing solutions, which are usefu=
l in their own right, but they also tend to work as really good optimizatio=
n algorithms because the nicely hybridize objective-driven and divergent se=
arch. We empirically found that they often do a better job at optimization =
than a traditional EA, even one that includes diversity. Illumination algor=
ithms are thus a subset of optimization algorithms that have the extra goal=
 of not just finding the single best solution, or a small set of solutions =
on the Pareto front, but instead of trying to find the best solution at eac=
h point in a feature space. 

Previous Illumination Algorithms include the =
Multi-Objective Landscape Exploration (MOLE) algorithm from [1] and Novelty=
 Search + Local Competition (NS+LC) [2], the latter of which inspired both =
MOLE and MAP-Elites. We thank Ken and Joel for continuing to have such wond=
erful, exciting ideas! Our paper lays out the differences between MAP-Elite=
s, MOLE, and NS+LC, of which there are many. Overall, we believe MAP-Elites=
 is simpler and works better than previous Illumination Algorithms, althoug=
h more work remains to fully determine the extent to which those beliefs ar=
e true. 

We look forward to hearing your thoughts on MAP-Elites. Of course=
, we would never normally post such a preliminary version of a paper, with =
incomplete experiments, insufficient controls, and not as much time to poli=
sh the writing as we would like, but several people are starting to publish=
 papers that use and/or mention MAP-Elites, so we wanted to provide a refer=
ence. It=92s also fun to share our thoughts about what makes the algorithm =
interesting and show some of the (unreliable, preliminary) data we have col=
lected about it to date. 

[1] Clune J, Mouret JB, Lipson H (2013) The evol=
utionary origins of modularity. Proceedings of the Royal Society B. 280: 20=
122863. (pdf) (video summary)

[2] J. Lehman and K.O. Stanley. Evolving a d=
iversity of virtual crea- tures through novelty search and local competitio=
n. In Proceedings of the 13th annual conference on Genetic and evolutionary=
 compu- tation, pages 211=96218. ACM, 2011.

Best regards,
=97 Jean-Baptist=
e Mouret
http://pages.isir.upmc.fr/~mouret/
INRIA Research Scientist
